Award.AwardTitle: Enriching the General Chemistry Laboratory Experience with Pedagogical Simulations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing and evaluating the Connected Chemistry Curriculum (CCC), which incorporates software that employs visual representations embedded in a modeling environment as the core component of undergraduate learning activities in general chemistry. Students participating in the curriculum visualize and manipulate individual molecules in a chemical system and visualize the result of their experimental manipulations. The software makes the information embedded in two-dimensional representations explicit, and provides visual displays of molecular interactions for students to observe, as well as multiple representations to foster conceptual understanding and emphasize connections between symbolic representations. The goals of the project are to 1) design ten self-contained learning modules and supporting materials that include CCC simulations as a core component to address student difficulties in learning general chemistry concepts, 2) optimize the modules using embedded assessments and field observations of classroom practice, and 3) evaluate the efficacy the modules for improving chemistry achievement via a quasi-experimental study that compares the achievement of students learning with CCC modules to students learning from traditional lecture and laboratory methods alone. The project is expected to strengthen the knowledge base regarding student interpretation and manipulation of scientific representations and the affordances of visualization tools for teaching chemistry, as well as inform the design of new visualization-based science curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This curriculum design project adapted and expanded The Connected Chemistry Curriculum for use in college chemistry courses. The curriculum incorporates visualization software embedded in a modeling environment as the core component of learning activities. This combination of visualization and modeling enables chemistry students to visualize and manipulate individual molecules in a chemical system and to visualize the result of their experimental manipulations. During the project, we developed seven curriculum modules (Matter & Measurement, Stoichiometry & Reactivity, Solubility, Acid-Base Theory, pH, Chemical Equilibrium, and Gas Laws) for a course in introductory general chemistry. During the project the research team conducted multiple protocol analyses and human-computer interaction studies to evaluate student learning from the materials and to redesign the materials to optimize student learning. Findings from an efficacy study comparing student learning outcomes between college students using project materials and students learning the same content without project materials showed students attained higher achievement after using project materials.

            Development activities also involved the design of a teacher professional development program for chemistry graduate teaching assistants who participated in project activities during year two of the project. The professional development program comprises a 10-week 1-credit course focused on improving chemistry college instruction. The program familiarizes teaching assistants with current research on the teaching and learning of chemistry and requires the teaching assistants to demonstrate their learning through a teaching practical. 30 teaching assistants learned to implement project materials into their teaching practice as well as novel lesson plans for incorporating visualization software into daily lessons. Due to its success, the program is now a required course for all doctoral students in chemistry at University of Illinois-Chicago.

In addition to the developed curriculum materials and the professional development program, project work contributed to the knowledge base regarding the potential of computer-based visualization tools for teaching and learning science, student use of multiple representations, and teacher-researcher collaboration. Pedagogical implications and project materials were communicated to researchers and practitioners at annual meetings of the American Educational Research Association and the International Conference of the Learning Sciences. Project findings were reported in three book chapters and two research journals.

Locally, over 500 college students have benefited from using project materials at the University of Illinois-Chicago, a large research-extensive university situated in an urban setting with a dedicated commitment to undergraduate STEM education. The University of Illinois-Chicago is an ethnically and racially diverse campus with a majority of students representing first-generation college students. African-Americans, Asian Americans, and Latino-Americans represent approximately 40% of the undergraduate population at UIC, many of who enroll in general chemistry as part of their major or as an elective.
